reviews.review_title: One of the funniest shows ever!
reviews.content: What We Do in the Shadows is not only one of the funniest shows on tv right now but it has become one of my favorite comedies of all-time. It reminds me a little of Seinfeld in which every character on the show is as equally as funny as the others. It's hard to pick out the best and everyone has their own favorite. It's based on the film of the same name and is created by the same people, Taika Waititi and Jermaine Clement. As funny as the movie was the show might be even better. It's one of the rare shows where every single episode is hilarious! There's nothing more I can really say except to go watch this show, I promise you'll love it!

What We Do In the Shadows is one of the best new comedies to come out in years, it's actually one of the funniest comedies I've ever seen! I absolutely loved the movie so I thought this was going to be a letdown but boy was I wrong...EVERY episode is great!

I was told to watch this by my son. It was worth it. The three vampires are hilarious. They are balancing being everyday citizens with being folks who suck blood and kill. Guillarmo is the guy who keeps everything moving along. He is called a familiar. He opens caskets. Rounds up virgins. And hopes someday to be a vampire. The first episode involve a visit from an ancient vampire, a nosferatu look-alike who pops out of a sarcophagus. He is apparently quite a stud but the others can't wait for him to be gone. One hilarious bit takes place in a stationary store where they are buying glitter and crepe paper (creepy paper?). Guillarmo has a rough time getting them to be accepted as normal customers.

For any who haven't seen the movie of the same title, it's highly recommended.I was worried the show wouldn't be able to capture the comedic genius of the movie, but i have not been disappointed in the slightest. It's fantastic!

This is an absolute beloved show of mine, and I love the mockumentary style, since the wonderful and political incorrect 'Death Valley', which had to disappear for no reason.The humor is very dry. The actors and their characters are why I fell in love with the show. Kayvan Novaks' and Mark Prokschs' performances, now basically the same over the course of four seasons, they never get dull. Between them, my beloved Matt Berry and incredible Nastasia. Demetriou do their thing with ease, while poor but sympathetic Harvey Guillen has the unthankful job of being their mundane servant (with some special abilities though). Kirsten Schaal, who I loved and hated equally in 'The last man on earth' becomes a very nice regular in season 4.Watching this show is like watching something from another age (hence my title), and I embrace every episode, great, good, or mediocre (yes there are some).Also, the title music and the ending songs, along with other music themes in the show, are great. Matt Berry as the great musician he is, has often his hands in it (especially in season four).The stories are often covering surreal facets of our daily life, and by transforming them into the vampiric lifestyle, they show how ridiculous these things are.Note that in my opinion the show has not much to do with the original movie (except vampires living in a shared flat), which I found nice, but not great. The show is much more sophisticated.The four seasons up to now (fall 2022) I would rate as following:
S01 - Hilarious entrance 9/10
S02 - A lot of wonderful ideas 8/10
S03 - Always surprising 8/10
S04 - Slightly decreasing story quality 7/10.

This show is hysterical. Reminds me of the British 'The Office' without the uncomfortableness. Some people said the jokes don't land but that's the point. It's supposed to be awkward. So glad I found this. Not many shows interest me.

reviews.review_title: Superb: in the same league as the movie
reviews.content: (Updated after Season 4).Four vampires and their human helper share a house on Staten Island, New York. Turns out vampires have domestic problems too.What We Do In The Shadows, the movie, was released in 2014. Co-written and -directed by Jermaine Clement (Flight of the Conchords) and Taika Waititi (Boy, Hunt for the Wilderpeople, Eagle vs Shark, Jojo Rabbit) it was brilliant: with wonderfully understated humour, sharp dialogue and clever skits it was quirkily funny and intelligent without becoming silly or even seeming to try too hard.The movie was set and filmed in Wellington, New Zealand and captured the folksy understated humour that is a New Zealand trademark. When I discovered that the series is set in the US, I had my doubts as to how it would measure up to the movie, figuring it had been hijacked by US producers and writers.I needn't have worried.Clement and Waititi are the executive producers and lead writers, so, while the setting has changed, the creative geniuses behind the movie are behind the series too. The series largely captures the same quirky, understated humour of the movie, but with different characters and actors, and the new players don't put a foot wrong.Not entirely the same feel as the movie: the movie felt more candid (as was ostensibly filmed by a documentary crew), giving it a slight edge but there is little to choose between the two.Four seasons in and the show is as good as ever, showing that the writers haven't run out of ideas. There's also a long-term story arc developing, making it even more interesting.

reviews.review_title: Way better than I could've imagined
reviews.content: This is so good I'm blown away by how enjoyable What We Do in the Shadows is! Well deserving of the 8.6 rating on IMDB, I'd agree with any great reviews. I love most the scenes and the main song You're dead is so damn good. Been skeptical of the series for awhile cause the humor but it's perfect, I'll definitely enjoy binging to catch up. I've absolutely fallen in love with this series easily one of the best out there!

My review (#224) will get lost in the shuffle, but I had to add something. I didn't read ALL the reviews, I eventually will have to go to bed, but the ones I did, I agree with, absolutely. This show IS brilliant, funny, dark, twisted and all that other devilishly wonderful stuff. The one thing I feel the need to add is a reference to Colin Robinson, played brilliantly by Mark Proksch. Ok, he's not one of the leads, but he's very, very funny in his own right. None of us will EVER know a real vampire (though sure, there are nut jobs who think they ARE real vampires) but we've all met Energy Vampires, THESE FOLKS ARE REAL! And it's great to see Colin interact with the regular vampires and the way they grudgingly accept him as one of their own, in some ways. I just hate the idea that this character and this actor are overlooked because, he's a very funny take on a very real issue. I'm glad he's been getting more screen time this season. Thanks cast, crew, producers for this fantastic show.

reviews.review_title: On the best shows on TV today... Hysterical :)
reviews.content: We never miss an episode. Since the movie by Waititi and Clement, we have been absolute fans of the whole idea of a house of vampires just trying to "get by" in the modern world. A hysterical concept excellently produced. All the actors embrace their roles to the hilt, and the comedy material is profound and abundant. The show just gets sillier and sillier... in the best way. Despite the concept - a house in the middle of the suburbs full of vampires who are kind of "nice guys" - they somehow make it tangible and even sympathetic. With all the vast number of "dark & evil" vampire tales out there, this show perfectly counterbalances the genre with some much needed silliness, presented in a thoroughly enjoyable romp every episode. Highly recommended, and I equally recommend you see the original movie for the greatest context.

reviews.review_title: It's the little things in life
reviews.content: This show grows on you if you enjoy Halloween and vampires and office comedy and mockumentary style shots. Keep em coming!

Funniest show on tv . Hilarious . The cast is superb and the jokes are non stop . Every season is better than the previous so at number 4 now and it's a true masterpiece of tv comedy . Not telling anyone what's it's about just watch and laugh .

I know it may sound strange to call this a workplace comedy but if a vampires job is to hunt and overall be a vampire then it fits. The show has that Office, Parks and Rec type vibe but add Vampires and yes it works and I love it. The show is funny and feels refreshingly original. I recommend this show to anyone who enjoys workplace comedies, vampires, or just wants to laugh. (Also it has a dope soundtrack)

Really kinda sad here...Just wrapped up Season 3 of What We Do In The Shadows and now have to wait for Season 4 - but at least it was renewed! This show is INCREDIBLE. Wonderfully written, hilarious, original (except for The Office/Parks & Rec filming style, of course) with a great cast, snappy and quick dialogue and a standout that improved episode by episode: Harvey Guillén's Guillermo de la Cruz.He really is the center of this show and impresses me all the time. Of course, he's gorgeous and I love his voice and mannerisms, but beyond that, he's the glue that holds both the show and the scripts together. I do love the entire cast, but this show wouldn't be half of what it is without him.And talk about perfect casting. ALL actors (and some puppets) belong in this movie and universe. I never once failed to believe these could be real-life characters and that's difficult for a show about the Undead.The show, about four long-"living" vampires living under one spooky roof with their familiar and being filmed as a documentary for them/mockumentary for us, is enormously funny and deep, as well. All seasons so far were great and Season 3 was by far their best one. There was even a surprising death I did NOT see coming and it 100% made me sad!! Even in a blatant comedy with hardly any dramatic elements. You just really learned to love this character and would have a hard time seeing the group without her/him.The Cliffhanger Season Three Finale also made me sad. I guess they ARE tugging at our hearts while disguised as a sitcom. I CANNOT wait for this to return and I might watch all three seasons back-to-back as I did just now before Season 4. I need to rewatch the movie, as well. I recall liking it a ton, but I LOVE this show. LOVE.***Final Thoughts: Quite frankly, Guillermo's story is tragic and despite him allowing himself to unsuccessfully try for unacquired love, I can truly relate to him. Guillermo spent 10+ years wanting to be a vampire and also possible love interest to one of the Vamps, and I did the same for about 7 years with a roommate. Now...he wasn't a vampire, as far as I know...

reviews.content: The original movie was hysterical from beginning to end and the same folks who wrote and starred in that one, wrote and directed this series. The entire situation is unique and different from anything else on TV, which helps to make it special. Don't miss it!
Short and sweet version....This is absolutely the funniest show on
I love this show. The writing and acting are perfect. It makes me laugh out loud. It is so clever.
Love this show. Great cast and fun show. Colin Robinson is a great character as the energy vampire

Aside from this show bring amazing, I just want to say that the set design and wardrobe are glorious, some of the best I've ever seen I appreciate it so much!!!Practical effects also!!! I hope wwdits continues for several more seasons:)

The 2014 film which precedes this is comedy gold and I was initially sceptical that this might be watered-down for a more mainstream TV audience. The location is different and there are new characters, but on the whole it lives up to the high standards set by the movie. The casting is spot-on and the acting flawless. The writing is inspired - this could be any family in any street in any town.Indeed, the appearance of some fairly heavyweight stars would suggest that those in the industry recognise the quality of the scripts. It has all the hallmarks of a cult TV show in the making. There is a ready-made audience of vampire fans of course, but these vamps are just so darn human that the comedy should appeal to anybody who recognises how utterly complex and ultimately insignificant people are.

reviews.review_title: The Office+The Real World+Vampires=What We Do In The Shadows
reviews.content: This show is an absolute blast. But I also acknowledge that it's for fans of a certain kind of comedy. If the randomness of The Office isn't your cup of tea, I doubt this will be either. And that's ok.An example that jumps to mind is in the first season where they are trying to figure out where to put up a visiting vampire in their house. Someone suggests the attic and Lazlo says "no the stairmaster is up there!"Stuff like that gets a laugh out of me. It's random and ridiculous and said by a vampire those things are just multiplied. Don't even get me started on the kickball game they have against the werewolves.This is a funny show. But you'll know almost immediately if it's your kind of funny or not. I'd say give it a shot regardless.

If you enjoyed the movie, or even if you haven't seen it, you're in for a real treat with the comedy adaptation about vampires in Staten Island. The larger cast, including the core couple Lazlo and Nadja, makes for a lot of scenarios that succeed in going beyond the premises of the film. Somehow after 3-4 seasons they still come up with some of the most inventive concepts which leave the audience pleasantly shocked. Brings together a lot of the character based humor one sees in UK comedies but with the New Zealand quirkiness you see in any of the film's producer's other work. There are also a lot of moments where you realize the characters care about each other, as well as inside jokes that come back over the time, rewarding the audience for paying attention. You will laugh and be amazed.

reviews.review_title: Seeing the bad reviews is just depressing
reviews.content: It's hard to dislike this show. It has so many gifted and just plain funny actors. It's not gut busting humour, but rather a mellow guffaw. How you can muster enmity against a gloriously silly display like this is beyond me.

reviews.content: I LOVED THE MOVIE, and the pilot just gave me the same feeling inside; creeped out, happy, sad, just please. I need at least 40 seasons with 45 min episodes. Thank you

Finally caught up to through the fourth season, this show is so gut laughing funny, and maintains is very high quality throughout. Would highly recommended for any fans of this mockumentary style comedy. Based on the earlier film of the same name, this series version follows the lives of a house of vampires living in modern day Staten island New York. It keeps the same comedic style as the movie, but extends the lore and fun across multiple seasons. There isn't much of an overarching plot, but slowly more character backstories comes in, and by the end of the second season I was quite hooked, it seemingly only got better from there. They keep up with the camera crew "documentary" style, where each frame has to be explained by a camera of some sort and lots of talking heads, office style. It works, its funny, would recommend.
With time and age the cast writers and directors have only gotten more hilarious. Don't miss it it's one of the best shows currently on tv.

reviews.review_title: Humour on a number of levels.
reviews.content: They've done well maintaining the style of the film with plenty of subtle humour mixed with laugh out loud slapstick in a very Goth way. Obviously life is hard as a vampire in the modern world. My wife loved the utterly boring psychic vampire.

reviews.review_title: Hilarious first two seasons, then drops in quality
reviews.content: Colin Robinson is hilarious. Great characterisation and really well executed by the actor. Genius stroke to portray an energy thief as a devious super white guy draining everyones' energy on purpose and even planning how to do it beforehand. The others in the show help playing him good too, by having the real vampires fear Colin and constantly being cautious around him.Nadia is fun too, with great timing and physical acting. Very talented actress.The problem is that after season 2, the quality of the show drops. I easily laughed several times during nearly every episode in seasons 1 and 2 and expected the same with season 3 onwards, but I find myself hardly laughing anymore.They started subtly adding more and more PC elements from season 3, although that doesn't necessarily explain why it's not funny anymore. That's just a mildly annoying thing that gradually makes the show less magic and genuine, which in turn makes you lose interest over time. However, PC writing might be an indicator of how the focus has shifted.The magic of Colin Robinson gradually decreased too. They started developing his character too much instead of continuing with the winning recipe. A character like that should be kept at a certain distance for the viewer, and the moment he starts acting like a normal, realistic, emotionally needy and vulnerable human-being he loses his magic at the same time. I wish screenwriters would realise this in other shows too.
A working class answer to "Interview with the Vampire". Hilarious with a never -ending series of funny situations. Wonderful acting

This is funny on every level. Everything is perfect, from the acting to the plots to the soundtrack. I want this to eventually have 10+ seasons. It's too funny!
That said, if you are a parent, maybe wait until kids are 13 or so, due to some graphic sexual descriptions (not onscreen content.)
Just as good as the movie but more friendly to an American audience. Great ensemble cast and doesn't get old or repetitive.Do yourself a favor and watch it!

reviews.content: This series is so on point. Love how they made the translation from the movie over to series. So good that Jemaine from the movie and (Flights of the Concord) is still involved in the production of the series. He is a genius!

I knew as soon as this motley lot invaded the city council meeting that this was gonna be my all time fave show. If love dark comedy, old school creature films, gothic tripe, smashing costumes, vampire lore, the office, and ridiculousness then this show is for you. The other fetching thing about this comedy masterpieces is it's inordinate number of scenes with trash pandas. Each character is uniquely absurd and they grow as vampires across the story arcs unraveling their twisted history. Funniest thing on tv since Arrested Development. It's the best! Don't hesitate to spend time with this irreverent crew of blood thirsty derelicts. Bring on the creepy paper it's a wild ride!

Talk about "What We Do in the Shadows" without laughing (pan to Guillermo now).I love love love this show. I'm tough on comedy series, stopped bothering with any of them years ago (no hope), but this one literally caused me to laugh out loud, and without my own consent, much to my surprise. You know how sometimes your brain processes before you decide whether or not something is funny? Yeah. You don't have time with this show. The comedic timing is a step above perfection. Excellent directing.The cast is great. I'm very critical of positioning, inflection and facial expressions. 100% on the deliveries, even for Colin, who is very very (double very) effective as the energy vampire. It's a struggle to watch and listen to him at times, but... it's supposed to be that way. And that, too, makes it funny.It's well done, it's cheesy, and corny, all the things that made Monty Python and Fawlty Towers great. But with vampires.If you haven't seen it yet, may Nandor hypnotize you to do so.

This has to be one of the funniest shows EVER. I'm late to the game but my goodness, am I glad I finally saw this. I finished the first three seasons in a week. I recommend this to anyone who is looking for something light-hearted to watch after a long day.Also - the best episode has to be when the Barron returns and gets drunk by drinking drunk human blood. I absolutely CRIED LAUGHED during this episode. I think this episode has some of the best written dialogue and performance.

The humour tickles me just right, and honestly it's constantly giving me a good belly laugh. It's not pretentious and doesn't take itself too seriously.The format of them filming a pretend documentary works really well, because it's a great way to have the characters monologue without it being weird, and you get a lot out of them doing it. It also doesn't do it in a way that looks poorly made.The situations they get themselves in is ridiculous in the best kind of way. There's some great cameos.I love all the characters, I couldn't pick a favourite, because they all really get their moments to shine, and all bring something great to the show. Honestly I love to binge watch this show, and I have done more than once.

I paid star plus just to watch this and I don't regret for it.It's as good as the movie, I love this kind of dark humor.Each character brings something unique to the series, that combination of vampire traditions mixed with current American traditions is extremely funny and ridiculous at the same time.

reviews.review_title: Way better than the movie its based on
reviews.content: A few years ago, my wife wanted me to watch the movie starring Taika Watiti called What We do in the Shadows about 3 vampires living together in the same house. While there were some parts that were funny, overall, I was not a fan of the movie at all. Watched it twice, nope.When the commercials for the Series came out, I was skeptical. But after watching the first episode, I was in love with this show. The characters are hilarious, the banter between them is funny, and the plots are hilarious. It has become a massive favorite of my wife and I. We have watched every episode almost 100 times each.

reviews.review_title: Funny and Entertaining When You Need a Good Laugh.
reviews.content: I prerecorded this and when I couldn't sleep one night, I thought I would watch it with the volume low as to not wake my husband. I ended up going to another room because I found myself laughing out loud-which is rare. Even though there were predictable parts, it still made me laugh-and It takes a lot to make me laugh.

As Collin Robinson would probably say. These guys become more of themselves and their quirks every episode! I am obsessed with it all and mostly can't live without Nandja randomly high pitched singing!! The dead sure do know how to make us mortals feel alive! Don't ever stop please.

I absolutely love this show. I'm so glad i discovered it. My roommate randomly suggested it and i was pleasantly surprised.I could not get enough of it. I watched every season twice .it is that good
To me I feel it's even better than the movie . Don't get me wrong the movie was great and I am still a big fan but the cast they picked for the series and just everything about it is amazing. They work so good together. Perfect dynamic for sure. I hope it come back for many more seasons. It is definitely my go to for comedy hands downI can't pick just one favorite character
10/10 definitely recommend.

Yes....it's campy at times. Yes...it's ridiculous at times. But.... I don't think I have laughed out loud during a comedy show like this before. The best parts are short, under the breath types of jokes and sarcasm that are comedic gold if you are paying attention. I was not at all prepared for this show when it was recommended to me. There are a few downer episodes with not as many laughs, but those are quickly replaced by episodes that will have you laughing again. The Nadia character is my favorite with Nandor a close second simply based on his slow and methodical manner of speaking. Watch the first few episodes and you will be hooked.

After completing 4 seasons this show is the best thig out there. There have been ups and downs, but the quality has been maintained throughout.Season 1 was all about the introduction of the vampires we love along with the human familiar Geill.. (Gizmo). Two of the major season plotlines revolved around Nadja, one being her long-time love affair with Gregor who gets decapitated in all of his former lives and the other being her adoption of the young girl Jenna and transforming her into a vampire. The plot twist as the season progresses is that Guil.. (Gizmo) who wants to become a vampire someday is actually a descendent of a well-known vampire hunter Van Helsing. Despite all this the best thing to ever happen in this show was Colin Robinson.In Season 2 the vampires deal with Zombies, Ghosts, Mailer Daemon, Witches and the Vampiric Council throughout the season while Gizmo is busy killing off other vampires like mosquitoes. What's intriguing is that in one of the episodes they introduced a regular human guy Jackie Daytona which doesn't make sense at all since it's a show about Vampires. Another outstanding episode is the one revolving around Colin Robinson, and his promotion, which tells a little more about an energy vampire.In Season 3 the plotline revolves a little bit more on Nandor and his personal life, Nandor tries to find love with a former lover Gail and tries to rediscover himself by joining a cult when that doesn't work out. Nandor along with Nadja become the co-leaders of the Vampiric Council while Laszlo, who knows of a dark secret, spends a little bit more time with Colin Robinson and go on various adventures including a boys night with Seanieee and a meet-up with a Siren. This season ends with every person trying to discover themselves while Laszlo takes a new responsibility of being a father.Season 4 shows us the development of the child that crawled out of the chest cavity of the dead Colin Robinson throughout the season, from a boy to turning back into the original boring energy vampire Colin Robinson. Nandor continues to find himself a wife which he accomplishes by the help of jinn magic while Nadja opens a vampiric nightclub with some help from the Guide. On the other hand, Laszlo along with Gizmo decide to raise the child that crawled out of the chest cavity of their dead friend Colin Robinson into an interesting being. Once Colin Robinson is back Gizmo realizes that nothing will ever change in the vampire house and decides to leave it and starts taking matters into his own hands.

Getting harder to find watchable TV shows, but I really recommend this little one. Extending vampires also to daylight dwellers, that sap other people's energy is a great, modern, tech-world innovation. Humor is always dark but sartorial, with very unexpected ironies between us and them, exacting huge giggles. That's it - five very likable characters, neither of whom are pushing any agenda, except to be funny, sincere and s-p-o-o-k-y. Well Done, Netflix.

I had to be tricked into watching the movie and loved it. I had the same misgivings about the TV show but watched and it's somehow better than the movie. One reason I think that the show stand above and apart from the movie is the lag time between them, strangely I think this is also the reason John Krasinki made the transition from sit com co star to Tv action man/ feature movie guy the lag time between the office and action man/ horror movie. I have always loved Matt Berry from the Mighty Boosh, IT Crowd, Toast of London but the Lazlo and Nadia characters and those that portray them are incredible talents that up til now have missed. I have not completely bought in to characters that at this point are in the realm of fantasy since Third Rock from the Sun, so convincing you buy these creatures exist and this is how they would act. So so good.

What We Do In The Shadows Season 2This show just gets better and better, always brilliantly inventive and inspired comic timing from the whole cast.Of cause everyone favourite is Guillermo, the much abused aspiring vampire!I look forward to another season as the joke has not worn thin yet, I hope they being back the Nadja's trainee vampire from season 1 as there is a lot more story to be told here.I love this type of silly humour, its not for everyone, perhaps more for a male audience, but I loved it.

Love this show. The characters are so endearing. So many witty one liners that you will keep laughing again and again. It a show that thoroughly deserves a rewatch as you will always miss some genius lines.Can't wait for the next seasons.

reviews.review_title: Love the movie love the show
reviews.content: The Matt Berry in almost everything he's done. reviews.review_title: Best show on TV. Or one of them surely

This comedy/ horror series is really well written with an amazing cast perfectly chosen for every roll. I've yet to watch an episode without a few good belly laughs and I've been in awe of the complex special effects/ CGI's. They deserve all the awards they've received.The one and only complaint... WHY ONLY 3 seasons?!
I went in judging because I loved the movie so much but this show is soooo funny. I love the cast. Brilliant like the movie.

I saw the movie and loved it so I was excited to see it was being made into a TV series. I admit I was a little skeptical about whether the show could live up to the movie but it definitely does. It is funny and smart and I loved every single episode.

SEASON FOUR
I have enjoyed "What We Do In The Shadows" immensely since it first came out. I continue to recommend this smart comedy to my friends and family that haven't heard of it. However... I might have to start recommending that they stop watching after the end of season 3 (which even seemed to slow down a bit to me in the middle). Right from the start, Season 4 started out with a jumbled plot and a stretched motivation for the characters that used to seem so natural. The actors were pushing the limits of their characters... But I do not mean a good "pushing" here. It felt more like when you've been hanging around friends for too long and some of their charming traits start fraying into annoying traits. The plot itself essentially goes in a big circle - and essentially nothing changes from Episode 1 to Episode 10... The story structure is very similar to the film - house of medieval European vampires house-sharing in modern America (transferred from New Zealand) are filmed by a crew of humans in a mockumentary format. There are two major differences: firstly, the TV series has no obvious narrative, unlike the film which was a build-up to the Undead Ball; secondly, the TV series replaces Peter the Nosferatu-esque ancient vampire with the masterstroke creation of an energy vampire. I loved this character. Everyone knows someone like that, who can miraculously suck all the energy and life out of a room of people just by talking at them; that's what makes it so funny.
I liked the clever way the source material was referenced by making Viago one of the Vampire Council, while simultaneously riffing on the idea that actors starring in vampire movies are actually vampires.
Actually, I think the episodic structure of TV serves this project very well, because it gives the creators more freedom to serve the jokes, and doesn't risk outstaying its welcome; comedy is generally at its best in bite-size chunks (pun intended). Even so, these were remarkaby short episodes, even for TV comedy. It left me wanting more, and I really really hope Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement are planning on producing more.

S01&S02I can't believe I started watching this vampire comedy series so late. It was a supernatural version of the "The Office" only in this case featuring the 'home' and lives of a bunch of vampires who are the quirkiest, craziest, and funniest examples of the blood-wraith kind I have ever seen or read about. And there's their familiar, Guillermo.Such hilarity, such deliberate and intentional production design and costume choices to communicate humour, and such wonderful performances all round. "What We Do In The Shadows" seasons 1 and 2 were both such a hoot to watch.I admit I got started on the first two seasons only after hearing the season 3 announcement. I had long been wanting to begin this series, and can't for the life of me understand why I took so long.Kayvan Novak's Nandor was hilarity made manifest. Matt Berry's Laszlo Cravensworth was tip-tip comedy at its subtlest. Natasia Demetriou's Nadja was perfection. Harvey Guillén's Guillermo de la Cruz was the best thing to happen to this show. The 'comedic balance' of Mark Proksch's Colin Robinson should not be underestimated.All other characters/supporting-cast were just as amazing in this series, which took a bizarre but superb documentary-filmmaking approach that I never would've believed could turn out so well.Various directors and writers came on board to craft different episodes, and each one was comedy gold. It took the best of some early British TV comedy programs, merged them using American TV comedy flair, and layered the lot with Continental themes and lore twisted to fit a funny mould. I loved every minute of every episode in "What We Do In The Shadows".The series was shot in Canada, and select places thereabouts. But the story itself was set on Staten Island, New York, and Brooklyn - two major locations. The places were well-chosen, and added to each season's credibility and comedy.Music by Mark Mothersbaugh was spot on.Norma Tanega's "You're dead" opening-credits theme song is still running marathons in my head.VFX, special effects, and makeup knocked it out of the ball park.This show is based on the 2014 movie after the same name. Taika Waititi collaborated on that one too.Various A-listers made appearances in select episodes. Tilda Swinton, Kristen Schaal, Haley Joel Osment, Taika Waititi, Benedict Wong, Evan Rachel Wood, Wesley Snipes, Lucy Punch, Dave Bautista, Doug Jones (as Baron Afanas), and the inimitable Mark Hamill all played memorable roles.The team behind this 2019 supernatural comedy series took vampiric stereotypes (and clichés) and organized them into a glee-fest worth every belly-laugh that the dialogues (and delivery of the same) inspired. Subtextual, symbolic, existential, truthful, debasing, awkward, inappropriate, macabre, and hilarious to a fault... No matter how late you may feel you are to this masquerade, just join already."What We Do In The Shadows" Season 3 will premiere in September 2021.

When the Kiwi vampire mockumentary went to television I didn't anticipate it being centred around three fantastically specific British cult comedy actors - even years into the series it still gives me a deep sense of cognitive dissonance - but they are a brilliantly cast anchor point of the whole show. Three silly and eccentric vampires flapping about with the wonderfully vulnerable familiar Guillermo and the droll wildcard that is Colin Robinson. Everything else is icing, and the core team are still brilliant together four seasons in, despite some mild Flanderization.The well-trodden semi-documentary sitcom format which the show is built on is shakily defined and inconsistent so I find the stronger episodes to be the ones that toy with their meta-filming narrative. The strengths of the show are the dark comedic writing, the satirical proddings at darklore and the central characters which are often remarkably fun - whenever it centrepieces indulgent cameos or leaps into cartoonish rabbit holes the premise begins to come apart a little - but as the series has gone on they've got far better at doubling-down on their own canon which makes it terrifyingly watchable.

Because I had previously reviewed Season 1 of "What We Do in the Shadows" in 2019, and absolutely loved it, I wanted to be sure to review WWDITS Season 2. Losing absolutely no momentum, the second season comes right out of the gate in startling comedic fashion, and even in the opening episode it is clear that the creators, Jemaine Clement and fellow New Zealander, Taika Waititi, have gleefully accelerated the momentum of this fabulous series. Bats continue to fly, coffins still creak, victims still bleed (quite a lot at times), and vampiric gags laced with slapstick continue to abound. Of course it's "not real!" It's great entertainment, the caliber of which will leave you immediately hoping there will be a Season 3 in 2021!

Just as wonderful as the worthy 2014 vampire mockumentary, "What We Do in the Shadows," this 2019 episodic series of the same name loses nothing on the small screen. High praise should go to the show's creators, Jemaine Clement and fellow New Zealander, Taika Waititi, for they have clearly taken great care to move this hilarious adaptation far beyond the limits of conventional television. The premise of the series remains the same as the earlier feature film: Ancient Vampires live together in a contemporary setting, feeding on hapless humans by night and sleeping by day. And like the film, the series is "documented" by a film crew who have been guaranteed they will not be harmed by their blood-lusting subjects. Even with the new and talented cast, and celebrity cameo appearances, a improvisational style of comedy is much in residence. Excellent writing allows the actors to adhere to the basic laws of malevolent Vampirism while simultaneously shifting to amusing lapses of poor judgement and cultural misunderstandings. (Try to imagine Vampires partying all night in the clubs, periodically "refreshing" themselves with humans, only to later find themselves "tripping" on their victims ecstasy-tainted blood). Bats fly, coffins creak, victims bleed, and vampiric gags laced with slapstick abound, yet there is also a genuine emotional, loving component, that will leave you hoping there will be many future seasons for this dark and delightful new series.

reviews.review_title: Finally,a new tv show that isn't crap!!
reviews.content: What We Do in the Shadows isn't even that new it's onto its third season.I am not a bot or paid review i genuinely love this show!Waited so long for a decent show ( 24, The Wire,Breaking Bad,Better call Saul, Homeland,The Office US&UK,Extras,The Walking Dead till S7...but only so many times you can rewatch even top quality)I've never even heard of the film of the same name (out before this) but after just discovering this show I'll now watch it.To give a sort of idea of what this show feels like try to imagine ...Bottomish,The Officeish,ITCrowdish,mildly Monty Pythonesque,Father Tedish,The League of Gentlemanly with special effects as simple as Red Dwarfish all cooked up into a fabulously hilarious mockumentary about a group of Vampires house sharing together in Staten island...(add in a pinch of Werewolves,Sirens,Witches,human Familiars & more too)The fantastic writing is showcased by superb casting choices.Facejacker & Four Lions Kayvan Novak plays a vampire,Matt Berry ITcrowd is a vampire,Mark Proksch from The Office & Better call Saul plays an "energy" vampire ( he feeds off peoples energy not blood) are familiar faces to me & highly entertaining actors.The remainder of cast I'm not familiar with but are just as brilliant with the characters of Nadja & Guillermo hilarious.Its dark (literally),small scale production,if The Mandalorian is an Aston Martin DB9,What We Do in the Shadows is a Yugo with four flat tires.But the lack of super cgi to me is an added bonus...its old school & fits the narrative perfect.A big thank you to all involved in What We Do in the Shadows & long may this show run.We now have a modern day tv comedy that doesn't try to be funny ...it just is.EDIT:After finishing s3 my only gripe is maybe producers could tone down the American characters because the humor seems to get lost in translation ..i.e the neighbour,Gail,Jan,The Guide,Simon.. watching them feels like an SNL skit...not funny at all.

reviews.review_title: The Office, if it was a Horror genre :)

This show brings me to tears every episode.

Despite a slow start the premise holds and we're introduced to a houseful of kids (average age perhaps 700+) who are pampered by a Familiar who cannot see that his importance to his master (Nandor) is slightly less than a pair of socks (to be discarded when worn-out, another pair will always be available).Despite being the only productive day-to-day interface between the Vamps and the real world Guillermo holds the household, and often the show, together with his ever-to-be-thwarted longing to become a vampire too despite a counterveiling dreadful secret.Colin is a clever metaphor for the very real vampires today; those who feed on disappointment and anger and boredom, they're everywhere... blocking tweets, discarding reviews, throwing insults on social media, vectoring to cross bored swords in the break-room first thing on a Monday morning. Everywhere.A clever premise with some star people. Kayvan Novak, Matt Berry (Toast of London, I Regress) and the endearing and surprisingly sexy Natasia Demetriou. Also plenty of special guest players to filip the viewership.A fun series. Watch Colin, I suspect he's the vehicle for all the modern ills of the digital age.

This show seemed slow to find its feet (perhaps I'm not a natural Familiar) but now that it has it's become something really entertaining.Guillermo wants so badly to be made a Vampire and can't understand that living a mere 70 or so years (perhaps less unless he sees a cardiologist and switches diets) makes him about as valuable as a pair of socks to a master who has 1200+ years under his belt.But Guillermo's dedication to the task at hand and his blindness to the moral compromise he's had to make to be good at what he does is a major driver in this show. Indeed without him we'd be looking at a bunch of spoiled kids who blunder their way through eternity.Characters to love nevertheless. Colin was tedious at first but his tedium became more endearing once I knew why it was his core activity. He develops well and endearingly. Nadja is perfectly formed for the drug-fuelled night-circuit in New York circa 1990 onwards but she's a great companion to Lazlo and their tumultuous (and improbably gymnastic and omnisexual) love affair is what binds them. Nandor is the best Daddy of them all, a binding grumbler, older than his 1200 years (he's already in his 1800's perhaps even 2000's) who holds the house together with his paternal pottering.Colin is a jewel. We've all known a Colin if we've ever worked in an office and he's truly an outstandingly splendid explanation for those Colins who have drained the life out of us by waving a cheery Monday morning greeting and swerved to revector and rendezvous with us in the Tea Room to whiten our hair with tales of his weekend.I'm a fan of Matt Berry (Toast of London, I Regress) and of Kayvan Novak but Natasia Demetriou is sex on legs, she's perfectly cast for this role.Looking forward to more.

A mockumentary-style sitcom, What We Do in the Shadows revolves around the lives of four vampires Nandor, Laszlo, Nadja and Colin Robinson who reside together. Each has their individual quirks and idiosyncrasies but they all struggle to fit in with ordinary humans and the modern lifestyle, often requiring the aid of Nandor's thankless human familiar Guillermo.A lot of the show's humour resides in the misadventures that ensue due to these powerful immortal beings trying to come to terms with the banalities of human pursuits. The characters are charismatic and light-hearted thanks to both the well-crafted script and the excellent cast performances. There is a ready wit in the dialogue with the interspersed interview snippets à la The Office being a wonderful addition. Finally, the fantasy world is realized vividly, praise for which should be directed towards the set and costume designers as well as visual and sound effects artists.Unfortunately, there has been a noticeable drop off in quality as the show has progressed. The jokes have become cruder (lots of sex and farts), there are more underwhelming storylines (like the Vampiric Council leadership saga), pop culture references are increasingly blatant (such as callouts to The Big Bang Theory) and the visuals have regressed. Most importantly, character personalities have changed too rapidly to be realistic - Guillermo transitions from a diffident helper to a manipulative vampire-slayer, Nandor's principal trait is that of gullibility and Laszlo's newfound chumminess with Colin Robinson is at odds with his earlier distaste. Some of the plot choices are also questionable - for example, the culmination of Season 3 which sees the separation of the vampires is rendered moot when the start of Season 4 sees them all instantly reunited. I hope that with the return of Colin Robinson, Season 5 contains more hilarious escapades, clever gags and lighthearted interactions instead of an overabundance of green screen scenes.Despite these personal misgivings, What We Do in the Shadows still makes for an engaging and entertaining watch. To catch some of the more subtle jokes, I would recommend watching the 2014 movie by the same name before commencing the show.

I cannot overstate how excited I was to hear that a show would be made from the movie that I had already come to love. This excitement was only enhanced when I discovered that the writers and producers of the movie would be the guiding hand for the show. This show has such an unusual sense of humor, such a dry, absurdist take on the premise of the vampire genre, that I was scared that they wouldn't be able to continue the momentum they started with the movie. Fortunately my fears were unfounded.Unlike sparkly, beautiful and completely boring vampires from a certain other series of movies, this show takes the form of a mockumentary that follows a group of ancient vampires dealing with the banality of day to day life in modern times. Orgies, vagina topiary, city councils, hypnotizing raccoons, office vampires that suck energy... this show has it all. One of my favorite quotes: "But, but, but! You're like a nonstop but machine!

It is delightfully absurd and ridiculously fun, What We Do in the Shadows expands on the film's vampiric lore and finds fresh perspective in its charming, off-kilter cast to create a mockumentary series.Love this comedy. Funny charachters and I lough through every episode. I hope this tv-show will continue for many more seasons.
So funny. Fantastic acting, hilarious comedy. Absolutely the best comedy show of the decade!!!

The first two seasons are easy 10s, but they lost me starting season 3. Guillermo wanting to be a vampire while also being a vampire killer should've been the main focus of the show, and they had a pretty great set-up for season 3 with the season 2 finale. But they pretty much threw it all out the window right from 03x01. A vampire bodyguard? What? And then they went ahead and got rid of that whole bit too, so what was the point, really? The season 3 finale had a half-decent set-up for 4, and Colin dying to be reborn was pretty neat, but again, starting season 4, they lost me. Within the first five minutes of 04x01, we see the crew comes back from their travels around the world (another completely redundant plot-line) only for the same directionless crap to go on from episode to episode. Colin is a child performer now? Why is he aging so fast? Shouldn't it be a while before he visibly starts to change at all, considering it takes him 100 years to age to what looks like a 40-y/o human? And Nadja opens a nightclub? But why? Not to mention Nadja's comedy has pretty much been reduced to just yelling stuff at people, unlike the first two seasons, where she was easily the funniest character of the show. And God, I love Kristen Schaal, but why is she a regular? The "Guide"? Seriously? The Nandor-Guillermo dynamic is all over the place- Guillermo refers to himself as a familiar in the last episode I watched ("Freddie"), so the whole familiar/not a familiar thing is gone too, I guess. The writers aren't even baiting the Guillermo-Nandor thing well, and when they try, it's so unbelievably cringey. Marwa served literally no purpose in the show. And then they essentially killed her off in the last episode, so like ??? What was she even there for?It basically seems like every development is pointless, temporary or simply a bad idea, and takes the show farther away from what it was supposed to be about. And please don't tell me these terrible ideas were written to lead to some bombshell development - it's a cheap tactic and only takes away from the rewatchability of the show. Shadows is turning into a bad sitcom with mostly filler content. I personally have no idea where it is going at this point, but if the past is an indication, they'll probably just chuck out everything from season 4 come season 5 to essentially be back at square one, minus a handful of irrelevant developments.

Always loved the original movie this series is based on and with a new cast and short time slots it has taken it to a whole new level. Kayvan Novak (FaceJacker) plays Nandor, haughty and naughty they all mix in well to make this show work seamlessly.I love the addition of Colin Robinson (played by Mark Proksch), a vampire that isn't your classic bloodsucker - he's an energy vampire that feeds by boring people and gathering their energy leaving sleeping bodies wherever he goes, he is also a daywalker.

Guaranteed you'll enjoy this low profile show, I hope it gets the audience it deserves and runs for longer than a single season.

Each episode is well structured, but also adds up to the main story line.The scenes are well set, and i can highlight the great camera work which makes you sometimes feel like you are being part of the story. Sometimes i get flashbacks from the Adams Family.Looking forward to season 2, and can recommend this to anyone who is looking for a casual comedy to watch.

reviews.review_title: The underdog show of the century
reviews.content: Why is this stupid show so good? It's like The Office but with vampires. If someone recommended this show to me with that description, I would avoid it all costs. I hate vampires and mockumentary sitcoms. But this is one of those shows with rave reviews that you decide to put off and maybe come back to when you have nothing else to watch. However, THIS is your sign to start watching this show. For some reason, it just works so incredibly well. It's great, I'm highly addicted to it, and it's so difficult waiting for next week's episode. This show shouldn't be good, but it is. The cast and characters elevate this show to the next level. And not even casting one new zealander was unfortunate.Even the brilliant Matt berry didnt save me from the let down this episode felt like to me.This was a major disappointment, since i know the original director of the film did this pilot. But missing him as a writer.... You cant direct yourself out of a bad script.I'm seeing people comparing to the office in the reviews... which i don't see at all. Being a big office fan... And when it didnt live upto them, i didn't see the different style of humor being used. I dunno. I don't like to think im that oblivious.. But who knows....Feels like people projecting their hopes for the show in replacement of the reality.I'll check out another episode after this one. But I don't have my hopes up.

It truly a gem in a dizzying plethora of new shows and movies unleashed by competitive streaming services. I have been waiting for a great vehicle for Matt Berry (of whom I'm a huge fan), so that was a pleasant surprise, but I'm delighted by the talent and comedic performances by the additional cast as well. Every single actor holds his/her own to continue the delightful energy of the original characters while radiating their own appeal and magnetism. And they carry the story along brilliantly and do great credit to the energy of the original. The writing is at least as equally clever as it's namesake film. My only lament that didn't discover it sooner. Don't hesitate. Find it and watch it!

I am a fan of the 'What We Do in the Shadows' movie, I thought it was extremely novel and funny. The TV show is also extremely good. I've recommended it to several people who said they thought it was funny !

"What We Do In the Shadows" is one of my favorite movies and I was very happy to see that a TV series was being made. This is a great little show with a brilliant cast. It's similar to but quite different from the original, as it is set on Staten Island ("it's where the ship dropped us off"). Kayvan Novak has slipped ably into the role similarly played by Taika Waititi in the movie, but Matt Berry (great Shakespearean voice) and Natasia Demetriou have created two new and hilarious vampires. In 2005, New Zealand's Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi wrote and directed a short (27 min) film called WHAT WE DO IN THE SHADOWS. This is a mockumentary about a group of vampires who live in one house and try to adapt to the modern world. They played the lead roles along with the excellent Jonny Brugh.In 2014, the short film became a full length film, with the same name and with the same cast of directors/writers/actors.Following its success, the film became a TV series in 2019. Waititi was already busy with bigger projects - he directed THOR: RAGNAROK and JOJO RABBIT (he won an Oscar for the screenplay and was nominated in the best film category). Of the 10 episodes of Season 1, Waititi directed the pilot, episode 7 ("The Trial") and the final episode. Clement directed episodes 2-4.In the TV series the cast is different and they don't play the same characters that were in the film but new characters, with the idea of the series continuing that of the film.In episode 7 of Season 1, the three original actors appear as guests in the same roles from the original film, in addition to other well known actors who appear as vampires (whose name is the same as their name in real life) - all of them previously played vampires in other movies/TV series.Another recurring role in Season 1: Doug Jones, who is already used to performing under heavy makeup, especially in the films of Guillermo del Toro.Season 2 begins this week. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: What We Do in the Remake$
reviews.content: On one hand, I am happy for the talented guys (Clement, Waititi) who made a flawlessly perfect early 21st century answer to "Interview with the Vampire" (1994) and now tapped into the North American market (meaning they hopefully get the adequate financial support for better future projects) with this cursed spin-off that contracted the incurable transplant contamination disease with many symptoms already present: Insipid writing, languid ensemble energy (damn you, spirit vampires), anemic main cast (except Harvey Guillén, Mark Proksch, you have one filler cast; in fact, the #1.7 "The Trial" episode shows that Danny Trejo, Tilda Swinton, and Wesley Snipes would be far superior choices to be cast as protags), the overall ham-fisted attempt at what's best a discount The Office-y vampire The Addams Family where the finest, subtlest, most intelligent funny bone-tickling quips this show can offer is "hehe funny vampire accent xD," and the glaring failure to capture or recreate the essence of what made "What We Do in the Shadows" (2014) work. A disappointing downgrade, like an empty cranberry juice bottle with a sticker bearing the handwriting of a 5-year-old saying "Bl00d (property of Timmy the Butcher. Mortals (mom), keep out!)."On another hand, I feel like making this show an exemplary "sacrifice" to pathetically ramble about the state of entertainment as a whole. If you are a single person living with your pet or two and putting this show on in the background as an emotional crutch to simulate living with "quirky roommates with sexy European accents" and giving it a 10 just for the sake of the warm feeling inside it gives you, you do you, boo, but I can't help but feel almost belligerent at how big yet simultaneously lazy our megacorporate overlords are, churning out repackaged brainless (oof, the irony) garbage for eons now. Disney, Sony, and Viacom could practically take over the government right now and it would be a bloodless painless coup, too, as masses in the street eagerly gather to welcome a rain of Baby Yoda plushies and dolls with "Yeed" that instant be declared the honorary president of the United States of America (the revolution will be merchandised) but I digress.What is it about good material that in the process of "adaptation" often gets butchered, its direction thwarted, and tone subdued whether the original makers were or were not involved in the production as this show proves. Sure, sure, you are smirking right now and want to rub "The Office" in my face, that one supposedly successful exception that proves the rule. Typically what happens is that when a show is taken out of its home place, tweaked a bit here and there perhaps to suit the "tastes" of the new place with the end result perhaps even bearing the same name or the same theme, chances it will have the same spark as the original thing are astronomical, case in point Red Dwarf versus Red Dwarf USA pilot. The will and the "skeleton" of Shadows is here but the spark is burned out.

reviews.review_title: Every bit as good as the movie
reviews.content: I was once up late some time ago and happened across the movie "What We Do in the Shadows" quite accidentally. I loved it and shortly after found out it had been made into a series. Now, my experience tells me that when a movie is made into a series, the series is never as good. Even when the TV series is good in its own right (such as M*A*S*H), it's still not as good as the movie. This time, I was wrong. The series captures the flavor of the movie and actually improves on the concept.What We Do in the Shadows (WWDitS) is a mockumentary following three vampires who share a modern house in Staten Island, as well as a familiar (a human who longs to become a vampire and therefore serves) and an "energy vampire", who instead of feeding off blood bores people so much they lose all their energy. Living for centuries has not made them wise. They are colossally stupid on several levels, which makes them oddly endearing.It's wacky, unpredictable and occasionally very gross. It is certainly not for everyone. But if this kind of macabre humor works for you, you might find WWDitS as adorable as I do. If you watch it at night, be careful not to laugh too loud; you'll wake up your wife.

I never saw the movie of the same name until after I saw all of the episodes of this show. I thought the movie was funny but, IMO, the show is the best. Maybe it's because I'm a huge Matt Berry fan. I only started watching the show because of him, but soon fell in love with all the other characters. I've seen all of the episodes probably at least 10 times. I even run all the episodes on loop while I'm stuck working from home just so I don't get bored during the day. I didn't find the show laugh out loud like The IT Crowd, but it's highly entertaining. If you loved The Office you're sure to love this show as it's filmed in a similar mockumentary style. I can't find anything negative to say about it. The acting is absolutely on point and the characters grow on you. While I do like Matt Berry I've come to really enjoy Kayvan Novak's portrayal of Nandor The Relentless. Nandor tries very hard to be scary and intimidating but turns out to be the one with the most gentle nature and kind heartedness. Give at least a couple episodes a try. I'm sure you'll want to continue watching. Can't wait until Season 3.

Completely unpretentious as ever, Kayvan Novak absolutely kills it as a thousand year old vampire along with the rest of the main cast who are all absolutely steller in their undead roles.
